A motion was brought alleging double recovery between jury’s award for future care costs and statutory benefits; motion dismissed. | Award will only be given if absolutely clear that benefits are certain to be received. There is a strict onus of proof and it must be patently clear that preconditions for an appropriate deduction have been established. It is uncertain if plaintiff will receive benefits. Motion dismissed.

comments: Dr. Olayiwola Kassim removed the deceased Mary Fleury’s appendix in 2011 during which time he should have discovered Ms. Fleury had metastatic adenocarcinoma. | Cancer was diagnosed 4 years later and Ms. Fleury died in 2016. Spouse could not work for a period due to depression. Spouse had to assume burden of caring for the deceased’s grandchildren which they had previously taken in. Ms. Fleury acted as the grandchildren’s mother.

other_damages.description: Future cost of care (25% included in this figure)

comments: Defendant guardians repeatedly sexually abused the plaintiff over a 5-year period. Plaintiff had been sexually abused prior. Sexual battery and breach of fiduciary duty. Plaintiff suffered serious emotional injury affecting her relationships with family, friends, and intimate partners. Loss of competitive advantage claim rejected because plaintiff was earning over $100,000. 25% reduction applied for pre-existing sexual abuse. Case decided on summary judgment.

Plaintiff’s cousin sexually abused her. Plaintiff had been previously sexually abused by her grandfather but managed that trauma well until abuse by cousin. | Plaintiff reported incident 7 years after the fact because of shame. Defendant found guilty in criminal court. This was a written motion for default judgment under Rule 76. Plaintiff could not maintain familial and intimate relationships with men.

other_damages.description: punitive damages (removed on appeal as excessive)

comments: Applicant husband assaulted respondent wife over 16 years, causing psychological abuse, depression, and anxiety. Trial judge recognized a tort of family violence, noting the wife's vulnerability as a racialized newcomer woman. On appeal, the Court of Appeal disagreed with the creation of a new tort of family violence and removed punitive damages as excessive.

comments: Plaintiff was subjected to false arrest, unreasonable search and seizure, and battery. Family Law Act s. 61(2)(e), Ethan (age 3)
Family Law Act s. 61(2)(e), Maximilion (age 4)

comments: Plaintiff was driving with her husband and three sons when struck by defendant who ran a red light. Collision caused injuries to plaintiff and two sons and killed youngest son. Plaintiff suffered soft tissue and spinal injuries, ongoing back pain, and lifelong emotional distress from death of son. Other plaintiffs (husband and two sons) had minor injuries and loss of guidance, care, and companionship. All five grounds of appeal dismissed; no bias found in trial judge’s comments about threshold regulation. | Trial judge did not err in permitting an expert to rely on evidence from Statistics Canada. Trial judge did not err in considering evidence given by a registered psychologist. The damages for loss of care, guidance and companionship under the Family Law Act were not excessive as to reflect an error in principle. Trial judge’s costs awards were proportionate.
